As shown in Tab.Â 1, our method consistently outperforms all baseline methods for each metric, especially in terms of Aâ€‹Dâ€‹Dâ€‹(âˆ’S)â€‹â€‰0.02â€‹dğ´ğ·ğ·ğ‘†0.02ğ‘‘ADD(-S)\,0.02d and 2âˆ˜â€‹2â€‹câ€‹msuperscript22ğ‘ğ‘š2^{\circ}2\,cm.
Compared to GDR-NetÂ [43], under Aâ€‹Dâ€‹Dâ€‹(âˆ’S)â€‹â€‰0.02â€‹dğ´ğ·ğ·ğ‘†0.02ğ‘‘ADD(-S)\,0.02d, we improves from 35.3 to 45.9, up to 30%.
Since these two strict metrics are usually utilized to measure performance in robotic grasping or other high-level tasks, the significant improvement of SO-Pose in Tab.Â 1 demonstrates that our method has great potential in robotic applications.

In Tab.Â 1 we demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed cross-layer consistency terms on LM.
We gradually remove Lcâ€‹lâˆ’3â€‹Dsubscriptğ¿ğ‘ğ‘™3ğ·L_{cl-3D} and Lcâ€‹lâˆ’2â€‹Dsubscriptğ¿ğ‘ğ‘™2ğ·L_{cl-2D} to observe their impact on the 6D pose w.r.t ADD(-S), 2âˆ˜â€‹2â€‹câ€‹msuperscript22ğ‘ğ‘š2^{\circ}2\,cm and 5âˆ˜â€‹5â€‹câ€‹msuperscript55ğ‘ğ‘š5^{\circ}5\,cm.
Thereby, we can observe that the accuracy decreases when removing either loss term, verifying the usefulness of our cross-layer consistencies.

id_table_2.caption:
Table 2: Results on YCB-V. We report the results of our method with different backbones. Ours(34) uses ResNet34 [6] while Ours(50) uses ResNeSt50 [48]. Ref. stands for refinement.
P.E. reflects the training strategy of pose estimator, 1 represents single model for all objects while M represents one model per object.
In general, the latter strategy benefits accuracy yet limits practical use.

As for YCB-V, we show our results in Tab.Â 2.
Using ResNeSt50Â [48], we outperform again all other methods under ADD(-S) and AUC of ADD-S, with 56.8 and 90.9 against second best results 53.9 and 89.8.
Under AUC of ADD(-S), we are only a little inferior to CosyPoseÂ [18], with 83.9 compared to 84.5.
Nevertheless, whilst achieving comparable results as CosyPose, out method runs significantly faster as CosyPose is a refinement-driven method, while we only need a single forward pass to obtain the final 6D pose.

We report the results of our method with ResNet34 [6] and ResNeSt50 [48] as backbone in Tab.Â 2.
Although the performance degrades slightly after changing ResNeSt50 to ResNet34, our method still outperforms most state-of-the-art methods, proving its efficacy regardless of the employed backbones.

We compare our method with state-of-the-art competitors in terms of Aâ€‹Dâ€‹Dâ€‹(âˆ’S)ğ´ğ·ğ·ğ‘†ADD(-S) in Tab.Â 3.
When trained with real+syn, our method achieves even comparable results to refinement-based method such as DeepIMÂ [19] and outperforms all other competitors.
Further, using real+pbr data for training, our method achieves state-of-the-art performance on 5 out of 8 objects.
Thereby, our average score surpasses all other methods by a large margin, with 62.3 against 24.9âˆ’56.124.956.124.9-56.1.

In Tab.Â 4, we report our results under the BOP setup.
To ensure a fair comparison with the related works, on LMO we only utilize the provided pbr data for training, whereas on YCB-V, both real and pbr data are utilizedÂ [9, 20, 43].
For all non-refinement methods, SO-Pose again achieves superior results reporting a mean Aâ€‹Rğ´ğ‘…AR of 0.664 compared to CDPN-v2 [20] with 0.578 and EPOS [9] with 0.621.
Nevertheless, we are a little inferior to CosyPose, the overall best performing method that adopts sophisticated refinement.

id_table_5.caption: Table 5: Evaluation of our two-layer model o top of another baseline method CDPNÂ [20]. We update the original CDPN to CDPN*. As for SO-Pose, we integrate our self-occlusion branch into the CDPN structure. Since CDPN predicts rotation with RANSAC/Pnğ‘›nP, we rearrange Eq.Â 8 and Eq.Â 9 to derive a new loss term Lcâ€‹dâ€‹pâ€‹nsubscriptğ¿ğ‘ğ‘‘ğ‘ğ‘›L_{cdpn}, as defined in Eq.Â 18.

Essentially, the consistency term â„’câ€‹dâ€‹pâ€‹nsubscriptâ„’ğ‘ğ‘‘ğ‘ğ‘›\mathcal{L}_{cdpn} is computed by replacing the predicted rotation Rğ‘…R in â„’câ€‹lâˆ’3â€‹Dsubscriptâ„’ğ‘ğ‘™3ğ·\mathcal{L}_{cl-3D} and â„’câ€‹lâˆ’2â€‹Dsubscriptâ„’ğ‘ğ‘™2ğ·\mathcal{L}_{cl-2D} with the actual ground truth rotation R^^ğ‘…\hat{R}.
Except for â„’câ€‹dâ€‹pâ€‹nsubscriptâ„’ğ‘ğ‘‘ğ‘ğ‘›\mathcal{L}_{cdpn}, all original loss terms in CDPN are preserved.
As shown in Tab.Â 5, after introducing our two-layer model into CDPN, the performance improves again significantly for all metrics.
This clearly demonstrates the generalizability of our proposed two-layer model.
